revision.text:
'''Abdul Haq''' ({{lang-ar| عبد الحق }}) is a Muslim male given name, and in modern usage, surname. It is built from the Arabic words ''[[Abd (Arabic)|Abd]]'', ''[[al-]]'' and ''[[Haqq]]''. The name means "servant of the Truth", ''Al-Haqq'' being one of the [[names of God in the Qur'an]], which give rise to the [[List of Arabic theophoric names|Muslim theophoric names]].<ref name=ahmed>{{cite book| title=A Dictionary of Muslim Names| author=Salahuddin Ahmed| publisher = Hurst & Company| location=London| year=1999}}</ref><ref name=rahman>{{cite book| title=A Dictionary of Muslim Names| author= S. A. Rahman| publisher=Goodword Books| location=New Delhi| year=2001}}</ref>
The letter ''a'' of the ''al-'' is unstressed, and can be transliterated by almost any vowel, often by ''e''. So the first part can appear as Abdel, Abdul or Abd-al. The second part may appear as Haq, Haqq, Haque, Hak or in other ways. The whole name is subject to variable spacing and hyphenation.
It may refer to:
==People== *[[Abd al-Haqq I]] (died 1217), Marinid sheikh (Morocco) **[[Uthman ibn Abd al-Haqq]] (died 1240), son of Abd al-Haqq I **[[Muhammad ibn Abd Al-Haqq]] (died 1244), son of Abd al-Haqq I **[[Abu Yahya ibn Abd al-Haqq]] (died 1258), son of Abd al-Haqq I **[[Abu Yusuf Yaqub ibn Abd Al-Haqq]] (died 1286), son of Abd al-Haqq I *Abu Mohammed Abd el-Hakh [[Ibn Sabin]] (1217–1269), Spanish Sufi philosopher *[[Abdul-Haqq Dehlavi]] (1551–1642), Indian scholar *[[Abdülhak Hâmid Tarhan]] (1851–1937), Turkish playwright and poet *Maulvi [[Abdul Haq (Urdu scholar)]] (1872–1961), Pakistani Urdu-language scholar *[[Adnan Adıvar|Abdülhak Adnan Adıvar]] (1882–1955), Turkish politician *Miangul Abdul-Haqq Jahan Zeb, or just [[Miangul Jahan Zeb]] (1908–1987), ruler of Swat (Pakistan) *[[Mehr Abdul Haq]] (1915–1995), Pakistani linguist *[[Abdul Haq Ansari]] (born 1931), Indian religious scholar *[[Shaher Abdulhak]] (born ca. 1938), Yemeni businessman *[[Abd al Haqq Kielan]] (born 1941), Swedish imam *[[Abdul Haq (Afghan leader)]] (1958–2001), Afghan leader against both the communists and the Taliban *[[Abdelhak Achik]] (born 1959), Moroccan featherweight boxer (1988 Olympics) *[[Huda bin Abdul Haq]] (1960–2008), Indonesian executed for terrorism *[[Abdelhak Benchikha]] (born 1963), Algerian football manager *Mohamed Abdelhak Achik, or just [[Mohammed Achik]] (born 1965), Moroccan bantamweight boxer (1992 Olympics) *[[Abdul Haq (ETIP)]] (born 1971), Uighur-Chinese alleged terrorist *[[Abdul Haq Wasiq]] (born ca. 1971), Afghan held in Guantanamo *[[Mohammed Abdelhak Zakaria]] (born 1974), Moroccan-Bahraini runner *Abdul-Haq, Muslim name of [[Anthony Small]] (born 1981), British boxer *[[Abdelhaq Ait Laarif]] (born 1983), Moroccan footballer *[[Abdelhak Boutasgount]] (born 1986), French footballer *Abdul Haq Bin Seidu Osman, or just [[Abdul Osman]] (born 1987), Ghanaian-English footballer *[[Abdul Haq Shafaq]], Afghan politician *[[Abdelhak Layada]], Algerian Islamic militant
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{For|the English fashion designer|Andrew Groves}} {{Infobox person | name = Andrew Grove | image = Andrew Grove.jpg | caption = Grove in 1997 | birth_name = András István Gróf | birth_date = {{Birth date|1936|09|02}} | birth_place = [[Budapest]], [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–1946)|Hungary]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2016|03|21|1936|09|02}} | death_place = [[Los Altos, California|Los Altos]], [[California]], U.S. | education = [[City College of New York]], B.S. chemical engineering, 1960
[[University of California, Berkeley]] Ph.D., 1963 | religion = | known_for = CEO of [[Intel|Intel Corporation]]. First COO and third employee, 1968 | notable_works = College textbook, ''Physics and Technology of Semiconductor Devices'' (1967)
Management book, ''Only the Paranoid Survive'', (1996) | awards = [[J J Ebers Award]] (1974)
[[Time (magazine)|Time]] [[Time Person of the Year|Man of the Year]], 1997
CEO of the Year, ''CEO magazine'', 1997 | occupation = Former [[Chief operating officer|COO]], Chairman and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]], senior advisor
[[Intel|Intel Corporation]] | spouse = [[Eva Kastan]] (1958–) | children = 2[https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-35221693 "Former Intel chief Andrew Grove dies aged 79"], ''BBC'', March 22, 2016. }} '''Andrew Stephen 'Andy' Grove''' (born '''András István Gróf'''; 2 September 1936{{snd}}21 March 2016) was a Hungarian-born American businessman, engineer, author and a pioneer in the [[semiconductor industry]]. He escaped from [[Hungarian People's Republic|Communist-controlled Hungary]] at the age of 20 and moved to the United States where he finished his education. He was one of the founders and the CEO of [[Intel]], helping transform the company into the world's largest manufacturer of [[semiconductors]]. As a result of his work at Intel, along with his books and professional articles, Grove had a considerable influence on electronics manufacturing industries worldwide. He has been called the "guy who drove the growth phase" of [[Silicon Valley]]. In 1997, ''Time'' magazine chose him as [[Time Person of the Year|"Man of the Year"]], for being "the person most responsible for the amazing growth in the power and the innovative potential of microchips." One source notes that by his accomplishments at Intel alone, he "merits a place alongside the great business leaders of the 20th century."''Movers and Shakers: the 100 Most Influential Figures in Modern Business'', Basic Books (2003), pp. 205–207. In 2000, he was diagnosed with [[Parkinson's disease]]; he became a contributor to several foundations that sponsor research towards a cure.[https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2008/0128/070.html "Andy Grove's Last Stand"]. He died at his home on March 21, 2016; the cause of death was unspecified.{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/22/technology/andrew-grove-intel-obituary.html?_r=0 | work = [[The New York Times]] | title = Andrew S. Grove, Longtime Chief of Intel, Dies at 79| first = Jonathan | last = Kandall| date = 21 March 2016| accessdate = 22 March 2016}} ==Personal life and education== Grove was born to a middle-class [[Jews|Jewish]] family in [[Budapest]], [[Kingdom of Hungary (1920–1946)|Hungary]], the son of Maria and George Gróf. At the age of four he contracted [[scarlet fever]], which was nearly fatal and caused partial hearing loss. [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 101I-680-8282A-38A, Budapest, Panzer VI (Tiger II, Königstiger).jpg|thumb|left|Nazi invasion of Budapest, 1944]] When he was eight, the Nazis [[Operation Margarethe|occupied Hungary]] and deported nearly 500,000 Jews to concentration camps, including [[Auschwitz]]. Its commandant, [[Rudolf Höss]], said at his trial that he killed 400,000 Hungarian Jews in three months.This statement is corroborated by information shared in his autobiography. See: Rudolf Höss, ''Death Dealer: The Memoirs of the SS Kommandant at Auschwitz'' (Amherst, NY: Prometheus Books, 1992), p. 39. To avoid being arrested, Grove and his mother took on false identities and were sheltered by friends. His father, however, was arrested and taken to an Eastern Labor Camp to do forced labor, and was reunited with his family only after the war.[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/22/technology/andrew-grove-intel-obituary.html "Andrew S. Grove Dies at 79; Intel Chief Spurred Semiconductor Revolution"], ''New York Times'', March 21, 2016. During the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1956]], when he was 20, he left his home and family and escaped across the border into [[Austria]]. Penniless and barely able to speak English, in 1957 he eventually made his way to the [[United States]]. He later changed his name to the [[Anglicisation|anglicized]] Andrew S. Grove.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/30/technology/30nocera.html|title=From Intel to Health Care to Beyond|last=Nocera|first=Andrew|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=2005-07-30|accessdate=2012-04-08}} Grove summarized his first twenty years of life in Hungary in his memoirs: {{quote|By the time I was twenty, I had lived through a [[Government of National Unity (Hungary)|Hungarian Fascist dictatorship]], [[Operation Margarethe|German military occupation]], the Nazis' "[[Final Solution]]," the [[siege of Budapest]] by the Soviet [[Red Army]], a period of chaotic democracy in the years immediately after the war, a variety of repressive Communist regimes, and a [[Hungarian Revolution of 1956|popular uprising]] that was put down at gunpoint. . . [where] many young people were killed; countless others were interned. Some two hundred thousand Hungarians escaped to the West. I was one of them.Grove, Andrew S. ''Swimming Across: a Memoir'', Hachette Book Group (2001) Prologue.}} Soon after arriving in the United States, in New York, in 1957, he met his future wife, Eva Kastan, who was a fellow refugee.{{cite book |last= Tedlow|first=Richard | authorlink = Richard S. Tedlow|date=2007 |title=Andy Grove: The Life and Times of an American Business Icon |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zQamXENAalkC&dq=Eva+Kastan+refugee|location= |publisher=[[Penguin Books]] |page= |isbn=9781591841821 |accessdate=1 January 2015}} They met while he held a job as a busboy and she was a waitress. They married in June 1958 and remained married until his death. They had two daughters, Karen Grove and Robie Spector, and eight grandchildren.[http://www.crownheights.info/index.php?amount=0&blogid=1&query=Andrew+Grove "Andrew Grove 1 of the 3 co-founders of Intel Corp"], ''CrownHeights.info'', July 18, 2007.https://www.legacy.com/obituaries/nytimes/obituary.aspx?n=andrew-grove&pid=178560960 Even though he arrived in the United States with little money, Grove retained a "passion for learning." He earned a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[chemical engineering]] from the [[City College of New York]] in 1960, followed by a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in chemical engineering from the [[University of California, Berkeley]] in 1963. ==Career== ===Helping start up Intel=== {{quote box|align=right|width=25em|bgcolor = Cornsilk|quote=When I came to Intel, I was scared to death. I left a very secure job where I knew what I was doing and started running R&D for a brand new venture in untried territory. It was terrifying.|source=Andrew Grove[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-22/andy-grove-taught-silicon-valley-how-to-do-business-dies-at-79 "Andy Grove, Valley Veteran Who Founded Intel, Dies at 79"], ''Bloomberg'', March 21, 2016.}} After completing his Ph.D. in 1963, Grove worked at [[Fairchild Semiconductor]] as a researcher, and by 1967 had become its assistant director of development.Henderson, Harry. ''Encyclopedia of Computer Science and Technology'', Infobase Publishing (2009), p. 218. His work there made him familiar with the early development of [[integrated circuit]]s, which would lead to the "[[microcomputer revolution]]" in the 1970s. In 1967, he wrote a college textbook on the subject, ''Physics and Technology of Semiconductor Devices.''Grove, Andrew. ''Physics and Technology of Semiconductor Devices'', John Wiley and Sons (1967) [[File:Andy Grove Robert Noyce Gordon Moore 1978 edit.jpg|thumb|left|Andy Grove, [[Robert Noyce]] and [[Gordon Moore]] (1978)]] In 1968, [[Robert Noyce]] and [[Gordon Moore]] co-founded Intel, after they and Grove left [[Fairchild Semiconductor]]. Grove joined on the day of its incorporation, although was not a founder according to the company. Fellow Hungarian émigré [[Leslie L. Vadász]] was Intel's fourth employee.{{cite news|title= Andy Grove's Tale of His Boyhood in Wartime|url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C04E1DA1238F931A25752C1A9679C8B63&pagewanted=all | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |date=2001-11-12| accessdate=2011-02-19 | first=Chris | last=Gaither}} Grove worked initially as the company's director of engineering, and helped get its early manufacturing operations started. In 1983, he wrote a book, ''High Output Management,'' in which he described many of his methods and manufacturing concepts. Initially, Intel primarily manufactured dynamic memory chips, [[Dynamic random-access memory|DRAMs]]. By 1985, with less demand for their memory, production problems, and the challenges created by Japanese "[[Dumping (pricing policy)|dumping]]" of memory chips at below-cost prices, Grove was forced to make radical changes.{{cite web|url=http://www.realworldtech.com/intel-dram/|title=Intel’s Long Awaited Return to the Memory Business|author=|date=|website=www.realworldtech.com|accessdate=8 April 2018}} As a result, he chose to discontinue producing DRAMs and focus instead on manufacturing microprocessors. Grove played a key role in negotiating with [[IBM]] to use only Intel microprocessors in all their new personal computers. The company's revenue increased from $2,672 in its first year to $20.8 billion in 1997. Grove was Intel's president in 1979, its [[chief executive officer|CEO]] in 1987 and its chairman and CEO in 1997. He relinquished his CEO title in May 1998, having been diagnosed with prostate cancer a few years earlier, and remained chairman of the board until November 2004. Grove continued his work at Intel as a senior advisor and had been a lecturer at [[Stanford University]]. He reflected back upon Intel's growth through the years: {{quote|In various bits and pieces, we have steered Intel from a start-up to one of the central companies of the information economy.}} Grove is credited with having transformed Intel from a manufacturer of memory chips into one of the world's dominant producers of microprocessors. During his tenure as CEO, Grove oversaw a 4,500% increase in Intel's market capitalization from $4 billion to $197 billion, making it the world's 7th largest company, with 64,000 employees. Most of the company's profits were reinvested in research and development, along with building new facilities, in order to produce improved and faster microprocessors. ===Management methods and style=== {{quote box|align=right|width=25em|bgcolor = Cornsilk|quote=Probably no one person has had a greater influence in shaping Intel, Silicon Valley, and all we think about today in the technology world than Andy Grove.|source=[[Pat Gelsinger]], CEO of [[VMware]][https://www.wsj.com/articles/former-intel-ceo-andy-grove-dies-at-79-1458609251 "Former Intel CEO Andy Grove Dies at 79"], ''Wall Street Journal'', March 22, 2016.}} As director of operations, manufacturing became Grove's primary focus and his management style relied heavily on his management concepts. As the company expanded and he was appointed chairman, he became more involved in strategic decision-making, including establishing markets for new products, coordinating manufacturing processes and developing new partnerships with smaller companies. Grove helped create the [[Intel Architecture Laboratory]] (IAL) in [[Oregon]] to ensure that software was developed in time to take advantage of their new microprocessors. Grove stated that "you are making decisions about what the information technology world will want five years into the future ..." He created a culture within Intel that allowed innovation to flourish. As CEO, he wanted his managers to always encourage experimentation and prepare for changes, making a case for the value of paranoia in business. He became known for his guiding motto: "Only the paranoid survive," and wrote a management book with the same title.Grove, Andrew. ''Only the Paranoid Survive'', Doubleday (1996). According to Grove, "Business success contains the seeds of its own destruction," explaining that "Success breeds complacency. Complacency breeds failure. Only the paranoid survive." As a result, he urges senior executives to allow people to test new techniques, new products, new sales channels, and new customers, to be ready for unexpected shifts in business or technology. Grove biographer Jeremy Byman observes that Grove "was the one person at Intel who refused to let the company rest on its laurels."Byman, Jeremy. ''Andrew Grove and the Intel Corporation'', Morgan Reynolds (1999), p. 65. Grove explains his reasoning: {{quote|A corporation is a living organism; it has to continue to shed its skin. Methods have to change. Focus has to change. Values have to change. The sum total of those changes is transformation.}} Intel Senior Vice President Ron Whittier notes that Grove preferred to keep open channels of communication between employees, and encouraged people to speak their minds: "People here aren't afraid to speak up and debate with Andy." They termed this style "constructive confrontation." According to Grove's successor at Intel, [[Craig Barrett (chief executive)|Craig Barrett]], "It's give and take, and anyone in the company can yell at him. He's not above it." Grove insisted that people be demanding on one another, which fostered an atmosphere of "ruthless intelligence." About that philosophy, writes business author Ken Goldstein, "you bought into it or got your walking papers."[[Kenneth F. Goldstein|Goldstein, Ken]]. [http://goodmenproject.com/business-ethics-2/many-lessons-andy-grove-gmp/ "The Many Lessons of Andy Grove"], ''[[The Good Men Project]]'', April 26, 2016. Grove's office was an {{convert|8|by|9|ft|abbr=on}} cubicle like the other employees, as he disliked separate "mahogany-paneled corner offices." He states, "I've been living in cubicles since 1978 — and it hasn't hurt a whole lot." Preferring this egalitarian atmosphere, this made his work area accessible to anyone who walked by. There were no reserved parking spaces, and Grove parked wherever there was a space. This atmosphere at work was partly a reflection of his personal life. Some who have known him, such as venture capitalist [[Arthur Rock]], have stated that "he has no airs." Grove has lived modestly without expensive cars or an airplane. Grove was noted for making sure that important details were never missed, with one of his favorite sayings being, "The devil is in the details." Intel Vice President Dennis Carter states that "Andy is very disciplined, precise, and detail oriented ... But at the same time, he has an element of intuition and creativity that is fundamental to Intel's innovation." According to ''[[Industry Week]]'' magazine, Grove feared that the "brilliance that sparked the creation of Intel" during its early years, "might come to nothing if somebody didn't pay attention to details." Carter recalls that Grove would even correct his spelling errors: {{quote|When he came to this country from Hungary in 1956, he didn't speak English. Yet I learned spelling from him. Not only does he have the instincts of a teacher, but he also has a great deal of patience.}} === "The Father of OKR" (Objectives and Key Results) Approach to Management === One of the earliest investors in Google, [[John Doerr]], called Andy Grove the "Father of [[OKR]]s" in Doerr's 2018 book, ''Measure What Matters: How Google, Bono, and the Gates Foundation Rock the World with OKRs.''{{Cite book|title=Measure What Matters: How Google, Bono, and the Gates Foundation Rock the World with OKRs|last=Doerr|first=John|publisher=Penguin Publishing Group|year=2018|isbn=9780525536239|location=|pages=31}} An acronym for Objectives and Key Results, it became central to Google's culture as a "management methodology that helps to ensure that the company focuses efforts on the same important issues throughout the organization."{{Cite book|title=Measure What Matters: How Google, Bono, and the Gates Foundation Rock the World with OKRs|last=Doerr|first=John|publisher=Penguin Publishing Group|year=2018|isbn=9780525536239|location=|pages=12}} The objective is the clearly-defined goal, while the key results were the specific benchmarks to ensure achievement of that goal were "measurable and verifiable." In 1975, Doerr wrote of attending a course within Intel taught by Andy Grove, where he was introduced to the theory of OKRs. Grove explained his simple but effective perspective on management: "The key result has to be measurable. But at the end you can look, and without any arguments: Did I do that or did I not do it? Yes? No? Simple. No judgments in it."{{Cite book|title=Measure What Matters: How Google, Bono, and the Gates Foundation Rock the World with OKRs|last=Doerr|first=John|publisher=Penguin Publishing Group|year=2018|isbn=9780525536239|location=|pages=33}} [[Larry Page]], the CEO of Alphabet and co-founder of [[Google]], credited OKRs within the foreword to Doerr's book: "OKRs have helped lead us to 10x growth, many times over. They’ve helped make our crazily bold mission of 'organizing the world’s information' perhaps even achievable. They’ve kept me and the rest of the company on time and on track when it mattered the most."{{Cite book|title=Measure What Matters: How Google, Bono, and the Gates Foundation Rock the World with OKRs|last=Doerr|first=John|publisher=Penguin Publishing Group|year=2018|isbn=9780525536239|location=|pages=8–9}} ===Preference for a "job-centric" American economy=== While Grove naturally supported helping technology startups, he also felt that America was wrong in thinking that those new companies would increase employment. "Startups are a wonderful thing," he wrote in a 2010 article for [[Bloomberg News|''Bloomberg'']], "but they cannot by themselves increase tech employment."Grove, Andrew. [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2010-07-01/andy-grove-how-america-can-create-jobs "Andy Grove: How America Can Create Jobs"], ''Bloomberg News'', July 1, 2010 Although many of those startups and entrepreneurs would achieve tremendous success and wealth, said Grove, he was more concerned with the overall negative effect on America: "What kind of a society are we going to have if it consists of highly paid people doing high-value-added work—and masses of unemployed?" He felt that employment growth depended on those companies' ability or willingness to scale up within the U.S. According to Grove, Silicon Valley's "innovation machine" over the last few decades has not been adding many jobs, although American tech companies have instead been adding jobs in Asia "like mad." He noted that while our investments in startups have increased dramatically, those investments have in fact resulted in fewer jobs: "Simply put," he wrote, "the U.S. has become wildly inefficient at creating American tech jobs." He therefore worked to keep Intel's manufacturing in the U.S., with the company having 90,000 employees in 2010.[http://www.foxbusiness.com/markets/2016/03/22/former-intel-ceo-chairman-andrew-grove-dies-at-79.html "Former Intel CEO Chairman Andrew Grove Dies at 79"], ''Fox Business'', March 22, 2016. He explained the causes and effects of many business's growth plans: {{quote|Each company, ruggedly individualistic, does its best to expand efficiently and improve its own profitability. However, our pursuit of our individual businesses, which often involves transferring manufacturing and a great deal of engineering out of the country, has hindered our ability to bring innovations to scale at home. Without scaling, we don't just lose jobs—we lose our hold on new technologies. Losing the ability to scale will ultimately damage our capacity to innovate.}} To remedy the problem, he strongly believed that "job creation" should become America's number 1 objective, much as it is in Asian nations. Among the methods he felt were worth considering was the imposition of a tax on imported products, with the funds received then made available to help American companies scale their operations here. However, he also accepted the fact that his ideas would be controversial: "If what I'm suggesting sounds protectionist, so be it." Or that those protectionist steps could lead to conflicts with our trade partners: "If the result is a trade war, treat it like other wars—fight to win." He added: {{quote|All of us in business have a responsibility to maintain the industrial base on which we depend and the society whose adaptability — and stability — we may have taken for granted.[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/26/opinion/andy-groves-warning-to-silicon-valley.html "Andy Grove’s Warning to Silicon Valley"], ''New York Times'', March 26, 2016.}} Grove was also in the minority of high-tech leaders when he advocated taxing internet sales made to other states: "I don't think electronic commerce needs federal or state subsidies in terms of tax advantages," he told a Congressional committee in 2000."High-Tech Chiefs Lobby Key Issues at Capitol Hill Hearing", ''Computerworld'', June 12, 2000, p. 8. At the same hearing, he also expressed his opinion about [[internet privacy]], stating that "personal data is a form of property and it's inevitable that governments will regulate property rights." He said that it would be better if the federal government established its own uniform privacy standards rather than have states create a patchwork of different laws. ===Writing & teaching=== Grove was also a noted author and scientist. His first book on semiconductors, ''Physics and Technology of Semiconductor Devices'' (1967), has been used by leading universities. Another book he wrote on business operation methods, ''High Output Management'' (1983), has been translated into 11 languages. He also wrote over 40 technical papers and held several patents on semiconductor devices. Grove wrote ''Only the Paranoid Survive'', a business book, whose core message is that a company in pursuit of a stronger competitive advantage never rests.{{Cite book|title=Market-Based Management|last=Best|first=Roger|publisher=Prentice Hall|year=2013|isbn=9780130387752|location=Upper Saddle River, New Jersey|pages=195}} He also taught graduate computer physics courses at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] and the [[Stanford Graduate School of Business]]. ===Philanthropy=== [[File:The Grove School of Engineering--Steinman Hall at City College of New York (CUNY).jpg|thumb|Grove School of Engineering-CCNY]] In 2005, Grove made the largest donation that the [[City College of New York]] ([[CUNY]]) has ever received. His grant of $26 million transformed the CCNY School of Engineering into the [[Grove School of Engineering]].{{cite web | url=http://www1.cuny.edu/mu/forum/2005/10/28/intels-grove-gives-26-million-to-ccnys-school-of-engineering/ | title=Intel's Grove gives $26 million to CCNY'S school of engineering | publisher=CUNY Newswire | work=News Report | date=October 28, 2005 | accessdate=September 30, 2016 | last1=Hershenson |first1=Jay |last2=Arena |first2=Michael}} Grove was also instrumental, as a key fundraiser, in establishing the [[University of California, San Francisco]]'s [[University of California, San Francisco#Mission Bay|Mission Bay Campus]], the largest ongoing biomedical construction project in the world.[https://www.ucsf.edu/news/2016/04/402311/ucsf-mourns-loss-andrew-s-grove-1936-2016 "UCSF Mourns Loss of Andrew S. Grove (1936-2016)"], UCSF, April 1, 2016. Chancellor Sam Hawgood said that Grove's "generous and tireless support of UCSF has transformed our university and helped accelerate our research into breakthrough treatments and better patient care." [[File:Mission Bay, UCSF.jpg|thumb|UCSF Mission Bay campus]] Among the research facilities which he helped fund were the UCSF Prostate Cancer Center, the Helen Diller Family Cancer Research Building, and the Clinical and Translational Science Institute. He also promoted general surgery initiatives and supported various obstetrics and gynecology research programs. Grove was a longtime member of the [[International Rescue Committee]] (IRC), along with being one of its overseers and a member of its board of directors. He was also the founding supporter of the IRC's Pathways to Citizenship program. In 2010, the IRC honored him as one of ten distinguished refugees.[http://www.rescue.org/blog/remembering-andrew-grove-irc-overseer-and-champion-refugees "Remembering Andrew Grove, IRC Overseer and champion of refugees"], Rescue.org, March 30, 2016. In an interview in ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' magazine in 2000, Grove encouraged the United States to be "vigilant as a nation to have tolerance for difference, a tolerance for new people." He pointed out that immigration and immigrants are what made America what it is.[http://www.esquire.com/features/what-ive-learned/learned-andy-grove-0500 "What I've Learned: Andy Grove"], ''Esquire'' magazine, May 1, 2000 ==Honors and awards== * Grove received honorary degrees from the [[City College of New York]] (1985), [[Worcester Polytechnic Institute]] (1989) and [[Harvard University]] (2000). * In 2004, the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|Wharton School of Business]] recognized him as the "Most Influential Business Person of the Last 25 Years." * The 1st Annual [[Heinz Awards|Heinz Award]] in Technology, the Economy and Employment.[http://www.heinzawards.net/recipients/andrew-grove The Heinz Awards, Andrew Grove profile]. Grove received the award in 1995, and he was honored by the foundation for representing a story "as old as America: the story of a young immigrant rising to great success." The donors of the award added that Grove "has played perhaps the single most pivotal role in the development and popularization of the twentieth century's most remarkable innovation{{snd}}the personal computer."Koven, Steven G.; Gotzke, Frank. ''American Immigration Policy: Confronting the Nation's Challenges'', Springer Science (2010), p. 81. * On August 25, 2009, California Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] announced that Grove would be one of 13 [[California Hall of Fame]] inductees in [[The California Museum]]'s yearlong exhibit. The induction ceremony was on 1 December 2009 in [[Sacramento, California]]. * [[Strategic Management Society]]'s Lifetime Achievement Award (2001)[http://www.smsweb.org/activities/awards/winners_2001.html Strategic Management Society – Home] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060923213131/http://www.smsweb.org/activities/awards/winners_2001.html |date=September 23, 2006 }} * [[IEEE Medal of Honor]] (2000){{cite web|url=http://www.ieee.org/documents/moh_rl.pdf |title=IEEE Medal of Honor Recipients |publisher=IEEE |accessdate={{Format date|2010|11|20}}}} * [[Time Person of the Year|Time Magazine's Man of the {{Infobox Christian leader |name=Saint Arsenios the Cappadocian |image=Arsenios the Cappadocian († 1924).jpg |imagesize=242px |caption= |alt= |birth_date={{Birth date|1840|4|7|mf=y}} |birth_place=[[Pharasa]], [[Cappadocia]], [[Ottoman Empire]] |death_date= {{Death date and age|1924|11|10|1840|4|7|df=y}} |death_place= [[Kerkyra]], [[Greece]] |title=Ὅσιος Ἀρσένιος ὁ Καππαδόκης |canonized_date=1986 |feast_day=[[November 10 (Eastern Orthodox liturgics)|November 10]] <small>(''[[New Style|ns]]'') / [[October 28 (Eastern Orthodox liturgics)|October 28]] <small>(''[[Old Style|os]]'') |patronage = }} '''Arsenios the Cappadocian''' ([[Greek language|Greek]]: Ὅσιος Ἀρσένιος ὁ Καππαδόκης April 7, 1840 – November 10, 1924) was born on April 7, 1840 in Kephalochori, one of the six Christian villages of the region of Pharasa of [[Cappadocia]] an early center of the [[Eastern Christianity]]. He had a brother named Vlasios.<ref>Γέροντος Παΐσιου (Εζνεπίδη), «Ο Πατήρ Αρσένιος ο Καππαδόκης», εκδ. Ι. Ησυχαστηρίου «ΕΥΑΓΓΕΛΙΣΤΗΣ ΙΩΑΝΝΗΣ Ο ΘΕΟΛΟΓΟΣ», Σουρωτή, 1979.</ref>
==Life== Born Theodorus Annitsalichos, his father was a teacher. Both parents died when he was very young, and he and his brother were raised by a maternal aunt. He was sent to be educated in [[Niğde]], where he stayed with a paternal aunt who was a teacher. She, in turn, arranged for him to stay with relatives in [[Smyrna]], while he continued his education. Besides Greek and Church Studies, he learned [[Armenian language|Armenian]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]] and some [[French language|French]].<ref name=Pemptousia>[http://pemptousia.com/2017/11/the-life-of-saint-arsenios-hadjiephentis-part-i/ "The life of Saint Arsenios the Cappadocian", Pemptousia, November 10, 2017]</ref>
When he was about 26 years old he went to the Monastery of the [[John the Baptist|Holy Forerunner]] of Phlavianai in [[Caesarea in Cappadocia|Caesarea]]. Later he was tonsured a [[Christian monasticism|monk]] and took the name Arsenios. Metropolitan Paisios II sent him to Pharasa and the neighbouring villages as a priest, while he was also secretly teaching the [[Greek language]] to the children of the region, at that time belonging to the [[Ottoman Empire]].<ref name=Pemptousia/> In 1870, when he was thirty years old, he was consecrated an [[archimandrite]].
After ordination, he went on a [[pilgrimage]] to the [[Holy Land]]. Upon his return to Pharasa, the villagers called him Hadjiephentis. He was the respected spiritual guide of the villagers and helped the people a lot together with the mayor of Pharasa, at that time the father of Saint [[Paisios of Mount Athos]]. He was claimed to have healed sick people who came to him, [[Christians]] and [[Muslims]]. He gave Paisios his own name at [[baptism]] despite the parents' wish to name the child after a grandfather. Later he became the spiritual father of Elder Paisios of Mount Athos.<ref name=Paisios>Paisios of Mount Athos. ''Saint Arsenios the Cappadocian'', Thessaloniki 2007</ref>
After leading his congrgation to [[Corfu]] at the time of the [[population exchange between Greece and Turkey]], he died after three months, at the age of eighty-three.<ref name=Paisios/>
Both Father Arsenios as well Elder Paisios were recognised by the [[Ecumenical Patriarchate]] as Orthodox Saints, Arsenios by the Ecumenical Patriarch [[Demetrios I of Constantinople]] in 1986<ref>«Περιοδικό Πεμπτουσία», τευχ. 1, Δεκέμβριος 1999.</ref> and Paisios by the Ecumenical Patriarch [[Bartholomew I of Constantinople]] in 2015.
==Works by and about Saint Arsenios== * [http://users.uoa.gr/~nektar/orthodoxy/explanatory/arsenios_kappadokhs_ermhneia_psalmwn.htm A collection of Psalms as has been given by the Saint ordered after the type of their specific use] (Greek) * «Λόγοι και Νουθεσίες», Κελεκίδης, Λ., Μαΐστρος 2015 (Teachings of the Saint brought to Greece as a manuscript written in the books of the mother church in Pharasa. Translated from the [[Cappadocian Greek]] into Standard Modern Greek and published. * Γέροντος Παΐσιου (Εζνεπίδη), «Ο Πατήρ Αρσένιος ο Καππαδόκης», εκδ. Ι. Ησυχαστηρίου «ΕΥΑΓΓΕΛΙΣΤΗΣ ΙΩΑΝΝΗΣ Ο ΘΕΟΛΟΓΟΣ», Σουρωτή, 1979.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://ypseni.wordpress.com/2009/11/10/st-arsenios-the-righteous-of-cappadocia/ About the Saint on the website of the Monastery of Ypseni] * [http://www.pantanassamonastery.org/who-is-our-venerable-father-arsenios-of-cappadocia-the-wonderworker-.html About the Saint on the website of the Monastery of Maria Pantanassa]

'''Assacumet''' (also known as ''Assacomet'', ''Assecomet'', ''Sassacommett'', ''Saffacomoit'') was an early 17th-century Native American from the [[Wawenock]] [[Abenaki]] tribe.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=fDcZzZmwcZgC|title = The Beginnings of Colonial Maine: 1602-1658|last = Burrage|first = Henry Sweetser|date = 1914-01-01|publisher = state|language = en}}</ref><ref>Robinson, Reuel. ''History of Camden and Rockport, Maine.'' Camden Publishing Co., 1907. http://www.davistownmuseum.org/InfoAboriginals.html</ref>
== Capture == Assacumet was captured in 1605 by [[George Weymouth|Capt. George Weymouth]] of the ship ''Archangel'' near the [[Pemaquid River]] in Maine together with four others. Some sources list the other four as ''Tasquantum'' (better known as [[Squanto]]), ''Manida'', ''Skettwarroes'', and ''Dehamda''; others list them as ''Tahanedo'' ("a Sagamo or Commander"), ''Amoret'', ''Skicowaros'', and ''Maneddo '' (listed as "gentlemen". Saffacomoit is listed as "a servant".) They were taken to England as slaves and curiosities.<ref>Biography and history of the Indians of North America By Samuel Gardner Drake. Boston, J. Drake, 1835.</ref><ref name=":0" /><ref>Rosier, James. True Relation of Waymouth's Voyage, 1605. Wisconsin Historical Society, 2003.</ref>
== Challoung expedition ==
In England, Assacumet and at least two of the other captives were given to [[Sir Ferdinando Gorges]], and learned English. In 1606 Gorges sent an expedition to America under [[Henry Challoung|Capt. Henry Challoung]] (also known as ''Chalowns'' and ''Chalon''), with Assacumet and Manida, to the [[West Indies]] and [[Puerto Rico]]. The ship was captured by the Spanish fleet and taken to Spain. The ship and goods were confiscated, and the crew made prisoners in [[Seville]]. Manida was "lost" but Assacumet was eventually "recovered", after Captain John Barlee wrote to Secretary Cecil, urging him to use his influence to win the release of the two "savages.".<ref>Biography and history of the Indians of North America By Samuel Gardner Drake. Boston, J. Drake, 1835.</ref><ref name=":0" /><ref>Rosier, James. True Relation of Waymouth's Voyage, 1605. Wisconsin Historical Society, 2003.</ref><ref>Drake, Samuel Gardner. Biography and History of the Indians of North America. Boston, 1835.</ref>
== Epenow ==
Returned to Gorges' home, Assacumet was lodged with [[Epenow]], a [[Wampanoag people|Wampanoag]] captive captured in 1611, and helped him improve his English.<ref>Biography and history of the Indians of North America By Samuel Gardner Drake. Boston, J. Drake, 1835.</ref>
In 1614, Assacumet accompanied Gorges' expedition under [[Nicholas Hobson|Capt. Nicholas Hobson]] to [[Martha's Vineyard]], where they had convinced him that gold lay in a ploy to escape, and where Epenow ultimately escaped.<ref>Biography and history of the Indians of North America By Samuel Gardner Drake. Boston, J. Drake, 1835.</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox Medical Person |name =Bennet Wong |box_width = |image =BennetWong.JPG |image_width =250px |caption = Bennet Wong, M.D., F.R.C.P.(c), D.Litt. |birth_date =July 16, 1930 |birth_place =[[Strasbourg, Saskatchewan]], Canada |death_date ={{death date and age|2013|9|25|1930|7|16}} |death_place =[[British Columbia]], Canada |profession =[[Psychiatrist]], [[Author]], [[Lecturer]] |research_field =[[Human Potential Movement]] |known_for =Co-founder, [[Haven Institute]] |years_active =1956-present |education =[[University of Alberta]], [[Menninger Clinic]] |work_institutions =[[Haven Institute]] |prizes = |url = |relations = }}
'''Bennet Randall Wong''' (July 16, 1930 – September 25, 2013), was a Canadian [[psychiatrist]], author and lecturer who co-founded the [[Haven Institute]], a residential experiential learning centre on the west coast of Canada, with [[Jock McKeen]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nanaimodailynews.com/news/haven-co-founder-dies-at-83-1.643260 |title=Haven co-founder dies at 83 - News |publisher=Nanaimo Daily News |date=2013-07-23 |accessdate=2013-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004222554/http://www.nanaimodailynews.com/news/haven-co-founder-dies-at-83-1.643260 |archivedate=2013-10-04 |df= }}</ref> His writings focused on [[mental illness]], [[group psychotherapy]], [[humanistic psychology]] and [[personal growth]].
== Education and honours == * [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D.]] [[University of Alberta]], 1955 * Postgraduate Training in Psychiatry, ''[[Menninger Clinic|Menninger Clinic and School of Psychiatry]]'', Topeka, Kansas, 1956–61 * [[FRCPC|F.R.C.P.(c)]], [[Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada]] 1973 * [[D.Litt|Doctor of Letters (honoris causa)]], [[Vancouver Island University]] 2012<ref>*{{Citation | last =Staff Writer | first = | author-link = | publication-date = | title =Founders of The Haven Institute to receive honorary degrees from VIU | newspaper=Gabriola Sounder | publication-place=Gabriola, BC | date=January 3, 2012 | pages = }}</ref>
==Career==
===Individual career=== Wong was clinical director at the ''Winfield State Hospital'' in [[Winfield, Kansas|Winfield]], Kansas, from 1957-59. He then practised [[psychiatry|adolescent psychiatry]] in [[Vancouver]], B.C., from 1961 until 1975. Wong was an early adopter of the [[encounter group]] process. During the late 1960s, he offered media comments on youth, including hosting a national television forum on youth on [[CBC-TV]]<ref>* {{Citation | last=Fewster | first=Gerry | title=Ben and Jock: A Biography | publisher=Oolichan Books | place=Parksville, BC | year=2001 | pages=54, 55 | isbn=0-88982-202-6 | oclc=48242601 }}</ref><ref>*{{Citation | last =Brown | first =Nancy. | author-link = | publication-date = | title =Sex, LSD, Lies, Theft Probed by Panel | newspaper=The Times-Colonist | publication-place=Victoria, BC | year=1970 | month= | pages =C1–C2 }}</ref> He discussed many issues with Canada's former [[Minister of Health (Canada)|Minister of Health and Welfare]], [[Judy Lamarsh]], and television journalist (and later Canadian [[Senate of Canada|senator]]) [[Laurier Lapierre]].<ref>*{{Citation | last=Lapierre | first=Laurier. | title=Men of Merit | newspaper=The West Ender | publication-place=Vancouver, BC | volume =2 | issue =4 | date=Spring 1981
| page=4 }}</ref> Throughout his career, he has been an advocate of [[humanistic]] approaches to dealing with children, adolescents and families.<ref>* {{Citation | last=Fewster | first=Gerry | title=Ben and Jock: A Biography | publisher=Oolichan Books | place=Parksville, BC | year=2001 | pages=56–59 74–76 | isbn=0-88982-202-6 | oclc=48242601 }}</ref> He incorporated the mind-body approaches of [[Wilhelm Reich]] into his work, as well as the perspectives of [[existential therapy]].<ref>*{{Citation | last =Gomori | first =Maria. | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | publication-date = | date = | year =2002 | title =Passion For Freedom | edition = | volume = | series = | publication-place =Taipei | place = | publisher =Zhang Lao | pages = | page =204 | id = | isbn =957-693-581-4 | doi = | oclc =62134500 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref><ref>*{{Citation | last =Allen | first =Wayne | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | publication-date = | date = | year =2005 | title =This Endless Moment | edition = | volume = | series = | publication-place =Waterloo, ON | place = | publisher =Phoenix Centre Press | pages =45, 46 | page = | id = | isbn=0-9684446-2-8 | doi = | oclc =56532288 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> Wong was a member of the Board of Directors of [[Moffat Communications|Moffat Communications Ltd.]] for twenty-five years (1973–1999). He has been noted in ''[[Who's Who|Who's Who in Canada]]''.<ref>{{Citation | last = | first = | author-link = | contribution = Bennet Randall Wong | editor-last = Whelpton | editor-first = E. | title = Who's Who in Canada | volume = 1 | pages = 1080–81 | publisher = International Press Ltd. | place = Toronto | year = 1977 | isbn=978-0-8020-9966-2 | oclc=21583544 | contribution-url = }}</ref> Wong was appointed as Visiting Professor of [[Humanistic Psychology]] at ''Hua Wei University'' in [[Shen Zhen]], [[People's Republic of China|China]], in 2007.<ref>*{{Citation | last=Hao | first=Tan | title=East Meets West in a Deep Place | newspaper=21st Century Economics | publication-place=Guanzhou, China | date=September 17, 2007 | pages=20–22 }}</ref> <ref>*{{Citation | last =Assaf | first =M | author-link = | publication-date = | title =Haven self-development programs foster international relationships | newspaper=Nanaimo News Bulletin | publication-place=Nanaimo, BC | date=December 24, 2011 | page =11 }}</ref>
===Partnership with Jock McKeen===
After working in individual practices in [[Vancouver]], B.C. (McKeen in [[acupuncture]] and Wong in adolescent [[psychiatry]]), they left private practice in 1975 to conduct residential [[encounter group|growth groups]] at the ''Cold Mountain Institute'' on [[Cortes Island, British Columbia|Cortes Island]], British Columbia. After the demise of the ''Cold Mountain Institute'' in 1980, Wong and McKeen helped to establish the ''Cortes Centre for Human Development'', and conducted seminars organized by this [[Non-profit organization|nonprofit]] society until 1983, when they co-founded The [[Haven Institute]].<ref>*{{Citation | last=Burke | first=Stanley | title=Care to Go Firewalking? | newspaper=Nanaimo Times | publication-place=Nanaimo, BC | date=June 1984
| page=5 }}</ref> Wong and McKeen challenge the traditional [[medical model]], encouraging physicians to be less [[objectify]]ing, to develop more [[self-awareness]] and adopt a more [[holistic]] approach to patient care.<ref>*{{Citation | last =Peterkin | first=Audrey | title=Find Time for Personal Growth, Students Urged | periodical = The Medical Post | publication-place=Toronto, ON | date=February 7, 1984 | year=1966 | page=44 | issn=0025-7435 }}</ref><ref>*{{Citation | last=Moser | first=Karin | title=Doctors Urged to Educate Their Patients | newspaper=The Free Press | publication-place=London, ON | date=May 23, 1979 | page=3 }}</ref> Wong and McKeen have taught this integrative approach in Canada, U.S.A., China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand as well as countries in Europe, South America, Africa and the Middle East.<ref>*{{Citation | last=Cornish | first=Murray | title=Healthcare in the Eastern Tradition | newspaper=Canada Hong Kong Business Magazine | publication-place=Hong Kong | date=May 1993
| page=7,8 }}</ref> <ref>*{{Citation | last =Walton | first = Paul | author-link = | publication-date = | title =Haven Founders release new book | newspaper=Daily News | publication-place=Nanaimo, BC | date=May 19, 2012 | pages = C1, C2 }}</ref>
===Establishment of the Haven Institute===
{{main article|Haven Institute}}
Wong and McKeen founded The [[Haven Institute]] in 1983, a residential [[experiential learning]] school on [[Gabriola Island, British Columbia|Gabriola Island]], B.C., and were active in its development until 2004, when ownership was passed to ''The Haven Foundation.''<ref>*{{Citation | last=Bulletin | first=Staff Reporter | title=Haven Reborn as a Foundation | newspaper=Nanaimo News Bulletin | publication-place=Nanaimo, BC | date=January 22, 2004 | page=24 }} </ref> Both men were appointed Emeritus Faculty of The [[Haven Institute]].<ref>*{{Citation | last =Sounder | first =Staff Writer | author-link = | publication-date = | title =Haven Foundation | newspaper =The Sounder | publication-place =Gabriola, BC | date =January 22, 2004 | volume = | issue = | page =3 | url =http://www.soundernews.com/fullstory/EpZulFyyVlMbDQGEip.shtml | pages = | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110716111640/http://www.soundernews.com/fullstory/EpZulFyyVlMbDQGEip.shtml | archivedate =July 16, 2011 | df = }}</ref> They were both given honorary doctorates by [[Vancouver Island University]] for their work in establishing the [[Haven Institute]].<ref>*{{Citation | last =Staff Writer | first = | author-link = | publication-date = | title =Founders of The Haven Institute receive honorary degrees from VIU | newspaper=Flying Shingle | publication-place=Gabriola, BC | date=January 2, 2012 | page = 7 }}</ref>
==Footnotes== {{Reflist|2}}
== Publications ==
=== Selected Wong publications ===
*{{Citation | last =Wong | first=B.R. | title=The Adolescent in Our Changing Society | periodical=Child Welfare | publication-place= | volume =XLVII | issue =7 | date=July 1968
| pages=411–416 | issn=0009-4021 | oclc=1071435
}}.
*{{Citation | last =Wong | first=B.R. | title=Obstacles to Understanding Youth | periodical=Canadian Doctor | publication-place= | volume =36 | issue =10 | date=October 1970
| pages=97–100 | issn=0008-3429 | oclc=1850301 }}. *{{Citation | last =Wong | first=B.R. | title=Toilet Training | periodical=Relational Child & Youth Care | publication-place= | volume =18 | issue =3 | date=Fall 2005
| page=57 | issn=1705-625X | oclc=52156766 }}.

See [[Jock McKeen#Wong and McKeen collaborative publications|Wong McKeen Collaborative Publications]] on Wikipedia's article for Jock McKeen
== External links == *{{commons category inline|Bennet Wong}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120323155903/http://www.haven.ca/about-us/our-founders.html Curriculum Vitae for Bennet Wong on The Haven's Founders' page] *[http://www.haven.ca/shenblog/?p=1300 "Loving is My Pleasure" - audio and written article] *{{YouTube|j0JdkEwsDuA|TV Interview with Haven's Founders Wong & McKeen}} *[http://www.haven.ca/shenblog/?p=988#more-988 "Psychology in China" - article by Jock McKeen & Bennet Wong] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110707212443/http://couplesalive.baremetal.com/?page_id=136 Downloadable Chapter from McKeen & Wong: ''Health and Happiness''] *[http://www.haven.ca/shenblog/?p=2051 Review of McKeen/Wong: ''The Illuminated Heart: Perspectives on East-West Psychology and Thought''] *[https://www.viu.ca/mainly/page.asp?ID=2139 Honorary Doctorate from Vancouver Island University 2012] *[https://www.viu.ca/convocation/pdfs/2012FebConvocationprogram.pdf Downloadable PDF of VIU Convocation Program honoring Dr. Wong]

{{Infobox person | name = Bothaina Kamel | image = Bothaina_Kamel.jpg |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|4|18|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]] |nationality = Egyptian |party = [[Independent (politician)|Independent]]
[[Constitution Party (Egypt)|Constitution Party]]{{cite web|url=http://madamasr.com/content/state-tv-news-anchor-announces-bid-presidency|title=State TV news anchor announces bid for presidency|work=Mada Masr|date=13 April 2014|accessdate=13 April 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413151559/http://www.madamasr.com/content/state-tv-news-anchor-announces-bid-presidency|archivedate=13 April 2014|df=}} |alma_mater = [[Cairo University]] | known_for = [[Political activist]]
[[Television presenter|Presenter]] }} '''Bothaina Kamel''' ({{lang-arz|بثينة كامل}}; born in [[Cairo]], 18 April 1962) is an [[Egypt]]ian television anchor, activist, and politician. A long-time pro-democracy advocate, particularly in [[Shayfeencom]], her professional career has been marked by repeated conflict with authorities. In June 2011 she announced her candidacy for the [[President of Egypt|Egyptian presidency]],{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/16/world/middleeast/16iht-M16-EGYPT-KAMEL.html?hpw|title=Muslim Woman Seeks Egyptian Presidency|work=New York Times|date=15 June 2011|accessdate=7 February 2014}} although she did not receive enough signatures to make the ballot.{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/98946/Egypt/Politics-/Bothaina-Kamel-poised-for-second-presidential-run.aspx|title=Bothaina Kamel poised for second presidential run|work=Ahram Online|date=13 April 2014|accessdate=13 April 2014}} She announced on 12 April 2014 that she would run in the [[Egyptian presidential election, 2014|2014 presidential election]] though she was unable to collect enough endorsements to run.{{Cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/99434.aspx|title=A two horse race: Egypt's presidential elections|agency=Ahram Online|date=20 April 2014|accessdate=26 April 2014}} Kamel hosted an Egyptian radio program called ''Nighttime Confessions'' from 1992 to 1998. She later worked as a new presenter for Egyptian state television, and hosted a show called ''Please Understand Me'' on the Saudi Arabian-owned [[Orbit Communications Company|Orbit satellite TV network]]. In each assignment, she eventually encountered official resistance: ''Confessions'' was cancelled after outcries by religious conservatives; she took a leave of absence from Egyptian state television rather than participate in propaganda surrounding the 2005 elections; and ''Understand Me'' was taken off the air by the Saudi producers when they became concerned that its coverage of the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]] would implicate Saudi interests. She has long been active in pro-democracy activities, often present a pro-democracy rallies, forming the election monitoring group Shayfeencom, in 2005, and immediately taking to the streets during the 2011 revolution. She is a self-described [[social democracy|social democrat]], and ran as an independent. A [[Sunni Muslim]], she has taken anti-sectarian stances, endorsing proposals for equal treatment of [[Copts|Coptic]] and Muslim places of worship and for trying those who incite sectarian violence. Additionally, she wears a [[Muslim]] [[crescent]] and a [[Christian]] [[cross necklace]] both are symbols of Egyptian unity and also were the symbol of the [[Egyptian revolution of 1919|1919 Egyptian Revolution]].{{Cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/83353/Egypt/Politics-/Expresidential-hopeful-Bothaina-Kamel-attacked-by-.aspx|title=Ex-presidential hopeful Bothaina Kamel attacked by 'Morsi supporters' - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online|website=english.ahram.org.eg|language=en|access-date=2018-03-17}} She criticized the military, rather than either sect, for sectarian clashes that have erupted in the wake of the revolution. Other positions include reducing the minimum age of parliamentarians from 30 to 22 in view of the youth participation in the revolution. ==References== {{reflist}} {{2011–present Egyptian civil unrest}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kamel, Bothaina}} [[Category:People of the Egyptian revolution of 2011]] [[Category:Egyptian democracy activists]] [[Category:Candidates for President of Egypt]] [[Category:Egyptian politicians]] [[Category:Egyptian revolutionaries]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1962 births]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Chris Gethard | birth_name = Christopher Paul Gethard | image = Chris Gethard 2016.jpg | image_size = 230 px | caption = Gethard performing in New York City in July 2016. | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1980|5|23}} | birth_place = [[West Orange, New Jersey]]<ref name= "biglake">{{cite news |last=Rose |first=Lisa |url= http://www.nj.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2010/08/new_jersey_native_chris_gethar.html |title=New Jersey native Chris Gethard to star in 'Big Lake' on Comedy Central |work=[[The Star-Ledger]] |date=August 16, 2010 |accessdate=December 22, 2012}}</ref> | occupation = Actor, comedian, writer | spouse = {{marriage|Hallie Bulleit|2014}} }}
'''Christopher Paul Gethard '''({{IPAc-en|'|g|ɛ|θ|ɚ|d}}; born May 23, 1980) is an American actor, comedian, and writer. He is the host of ''[[The Chris Gethard Show]]'', a talk show based in [[New York City]] that began airing in 2011 and was cancelled in 2018. He also hosts the podcast ''Beautiful Stories From Anonymous People''.
==Early life== [[File:Chris Gethard Show.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Gethard taping ''[[The Chris Gethard Show]]'' in September 2011]] Gethard grew up in [[West Orange, New Jersey]], the son of Sally and Ken Gethard,<ref>{{cite web|title=Beautiful/Anonymous: "Sorry Sally" T-Shirt - PodSwag|url=https://www.podswag.com/products/beautiful-anonymous-sorry-sally-tee?variant=31477573777|website=PodSwag|language=en|quote=Chris Gethard's mother, Sally,}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ask a Grown-Up - This American Life|url=https://www.thisamericanlife.org/612/ask-a-grown-up|website=This American Life|date=March 17, 2017|quote=Then we found Ken Gethard, comedian Chris Gethard's dad,}}</ref> and attended [[West Orange High School (New Jersey)|West Orange High School]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mishkin|first1=Budd|title=One On 1 Profile: Comedian Chris Gethard Offers a Unique Approach to the Entertainment Industry With His Public Access Following|url=http://www.twcnews.com/archives/nyc/all-boroughs/2014/05/12/one-on-1-profile--comedian-chris-gethard-offers-a-unique-approach-to-the-entertainment-industry-with-his-public-access-following-NYC_208524.old.html|work=NY1|date=May 13, 2014|language=en|quote=It's not every comedian who can say they played Giants Stadium. Chris Gethard did with the 1996 West Orange, N.J. High School Marching Mountaineers.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170811050919/http://www.twcnews.com/archives/nyc/all-boroughs/2014/05/12/one-on-1-profile--comedian-chris-gethard-offers-a-unique-approach-to-the-entertainment-industry-with-his-public-access-following-NYC_208524.old.html|archivedate=August 11, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He is of Irish descent.
==Career== Gethard is an improvisational actor who works largely out of [[Manhattan]]'s [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre]]. He began taking classes at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre in 2000 while he was a student at [[Rutgers University]].<ref name="ny_mag">{{cite web|last=Raftery|first=Brian|title=The Carson of Cable Access|url=http://nymag.com/arts/tv/features/chris-gethard-2012-4/|work=New York Magazine|accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref> He is in the longform improvisation team The Stepfathers. He organizes a monthly show entitled "The Nights of Our Lives".{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} He has also been part of the UCB Theater's national touring company. An early noted work was entitled ''Darryl'', a one-man show where he portrayed troubled baseball player [[Darryl Strawberry]].{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}
Gethard also wrote the web series ''The Most Awkward Boy in the World'' which starred fellow Stepfathers member [[Zach Woods]].
Gethard was featured on [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] magazine's "Ten Comics to Watch in 2010" list.
Gethard has appeared in multiple [[CollegeHumor.com]] videos. He has also appeared on ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', ''[[Hope and Faith]]'' and [[Comedy Central]]'s ''[[Crossballs]]''.
In April 2010, he was tapped as the lead, alongside [[Horatio Sanz]] and [[Chris Parnell]], in the [[Comedy Central]] sitcom ''[[Big Lake (TV series)|Big Lake]]''. In May 2012, during the CollegeHumor [[CollegeHumor#CH Originals|All-Nighter]], Gethard announced he would be opening a strawberry farm in upper New Jersey.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}
In 2013, the [[IFC (U.S. TV channel)|Independent Film Channel]] asked Gethard to write a pilot based on his book, ''A Bad Idea I'm About to Do''. IFC gave Gethard a year, in addition to writing his pilot, to market for them at festivals and produce web content.<ref name="av_club_ifc">{{cite web|last=Heisler|first=Steve|title=Chris Gethard explains his new IFC deal and how he makes his public-access show|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/chris-gethard-explains-his-new-ifc-deal-and-how-he,92509/|work=A.V. Club|accessdate=August 14, 2013}}</ref>
Gethard released his first comedy album, ''[[My Comedy Album]]'', on April 22, 2014 on New Jersey's [[Don Giovanni Records]].
In August 2016 Gethard participated for the first time in the [[Edinburgh Festival Fringe]], performing his show ''Career Suicide'' dealing with his experiences of depression, suicide attempts and alcoholism.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2016/jul/30/chris-gethard-depression-standup-comedy | title=Chris Gethard: turning shame and pain into laughs | date=July 30, 2016 | work=The Guardian | first=Seth |last=Colter Walls }}</ref> During his run at the festival, he also recorded an episode of [[Stuart Goldsmith]]'s "Comedian's Comedian Podcast", which was published in December 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=189 – Chris Gethard {{!}} The Comedian's Comedian|url=http://www.comedianscomedian.com/189-chris-gethard/|website=comedianscomedian.com|language=en}}</ref>
On May 6, 2017 [[HBO]] broadcast ''Career Suicide,'' an evening of standup comedy based on Gethard's [[off-Broadway]] show of the same title.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/chris-gethards-off-broadway-career-suicide-sets-hbo-air-date|title=Chris Gethard’s Off-Broadway Career Suicide Sets HBO Air Date {{!}} Playbill|website=Playbill|language=en|access-date=June 7, 2017}}</ref> Produced by [[Judd Apatow]], the HBO special has garnered praise from [[Time (magazine)|Time Magazine]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4767866/chris-gethard-career-suicide-hbo/|title=Comedian Chris Gethard Is Risking His Career to Tackle This Topic|last=Chan|first=Melissa|website=Time|access-date=June 7, 2017|date=May 5, 2017}}</ref> [[NPR]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/monkeysee/2017/05/06/526892264/chris-gethard-isnt-kidding-about-career-suicide|title=Chris Gethard Isn't Kidding About 'Career Suicide'|work=NPR.org|access-date=June 7, 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|date=May 6, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170607050610/http://www.npr.org/sections/monkeysee/2017/05/06/526892264/chris-gethard-isnt-kidding-about-career-suicide|archivedate=June 7, 2017|df=|first=Linda|last=Holmes}}</ref> the [[The A.V. Club|A.V. Club]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/it-takes-strength-be-gentle-kind-and-funny-chris-g-254791|first=Erik|last=Adams|publisher=AV Club|title=It takes strength to be as gentle, kind, and funny as Chris Gethard’s Career Suicide|date=May 5, 2017|access-date=June 7, 2017}}</ref> [[USA Today]],<ref>{{Cite 6, 2017|df=}}</ref> [[Paste (magazine)|Paste Magazine]],<ref>{{Cite news|first=Graham|last=Techler|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2017/05/-career-suicide-airs-on.html|title=In His Superb Career Suicide, Heaven Knows Chris Gethard's Miserable Now|work=pastemagazine.com|access-date=June 7, 2017|language=en|date=May 6, 2017}}</ref> [[HuffPost|The Huffington Post]]<ref>{{Cite Comedy|last=Capewell|first=Jillian|date=May 4, 2017|work=Huffington Post|access-date=June 7, 2017|language=en-US}}</ref> and [[Splitsider]].<ref>{{Cite 2017|df=|first=Erik|last=Abriss}}</ref>
===''The Chris Gethard Show''=== Gethard hosted ''[[The Chris Gethard Show]]'', a talkshow that originally aired on [[New York City]] public-access and was streamed around the world on Gethard's website. The show began as a live piece at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in 2009. Gethard then went to [[Los Angeles]] to pitch a network version of the show, but ended up returning to New York City to produce it for public-access because he wanted to retain the chaotic, cheap feel of early [[MTV]] talk shows. The show has since grown to consist of both stage and filmed performances. It has developed a reputation for outrageous spectacle, often featuring awkward viewer calls, high-concept group segments and Gethard subjecting himself to abuse, including an episode where he hired a kickboxer to hit him if he failed to answer simple questions about his friends.<ref name="ny_mag" /> As a child, Gethard admired comedians who seemed to be able to do whatever they wanted, such as Howard Stern, Andy Kaufman, and David Letterman. This interest influenced the style of ''The Chris Gethard Show'' and Gethard's comedic persona.
The show was entirely self-funded and none of the performers were paid for their time during its public access time. Though this largely surfaced as result of the style of Upright Citizens Brigade shows and the aesthetic of the show, Gethard had stated that he would not be opposed to the show being picked up by a television network. He met with a number of network producers, but the show was not picked up, the primary concern being its unpredictable nature and frequent swearing.<ref name=av_club_ifc /> In early 2014, Comedy Central ordered a pilot from TCGS, to be co-produced by Funny or Die, leading to a brief hiatus from the weekly program. The pilot was taped, but ultimately not picked up by Comedy Central. The show returned to MNN from April to January 2015. In its final MNN episode it was announced that the show had been picked up by [[Fusion (TV channel)|Fusion]], where it ran for two seasons.
Throughout the show's many manifestations, it has attracted a number of celebrity guests including [[Sean Combs|P. Diddy]], [[Amy Poehler]], [[Will Ferrell]], [[Paul Giamatti]], and [[Lena Dunham]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2017/05/the-chris-gethard-show-trutv-chris-gethard-live-1202083483/|title=‘The Chris Gethard Show’ Lands At TruTV; Will Be Broadcast Live|last=Petski|first=Denise|date=May 4, 2017|work=Deadline|access-date=June 7, 2017|language=en-US|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170506085005/http://deadline.com/2017/05/the-chris-gethard-show-trutv-chris-gethard-live-1202083483/|archivedate=May 6, 2017|df=}}</ref>
After its run on Fusion, ''The Chris Gethard Show'' was picked up for a third season by [[truTV]], and began airing live episodes in August 2017.<ref name=":0" /> In August 2018, Chris Gethard announced the show had been canceled and would not return for another season.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2018/08/chris-gethard-announces-the-end-of-the-chris-gethard-show.html|title=Chris Gethard Announces the End of The Chris Gethard Show|last=Wright|first=Megh|work=Vulture|access-date=2018-08-16|language=en}}</ref>
===''Beautiful/Anonymous''=== Gethard is currently the host of [[Earwolf]]'s podcast ''Beautiful/Anonymous'', which first aired on March 15, 2016. The following is Earwolf's description of the show: "1 phone call. 1 hour. No names. No holds barred. That’s the premise behind ''Beautiful Stories from Anonymous People'', hosted by comedian Chris Gethard...Every week, Chris opens the phone line to one anonymous caller, and he can’t hang up first, no matter what. From shocking confessions and family secrets to philosophical discussions and shameless self-promotion, anything can and will happen!"<ref>[http://www.earwolf.com/show/beautiful-anonymous/ Beautiful Stories From Anonymous People], ''Earwolf'', Retrieved March 20, 2018.</ref>
===''In Your Dreams''=== Gethard co-hosted [[Earwolf]]'s podcast, ''In Your Dreams'', with Gary Richardson.<ref name="In Your Dreams">[http://www.earwolf.com/show/in-your-dreams/ In Your Dreams with Chris Gethard, presented by Casper] ''Earwolf'', Retrieved March 20, 2018.</ref> The podcast first aired on December 12, 2016 with special guest comedian [[Aparna Nancherla]], and the ninth and final episode aired on February 6, 2017.<ref name="In Your Dreams" />
===Books=== Gethard is also the author of ''Weird NY'', a book detailing the [[Ghost story|ghost stories]] and [[urban legends]] of [[New York City]], and ''A Bad Idea I'm About to Do'', a collection of stories from Gethard's life, which has been highlighted on [[This American Life]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/453/nemeses |title=Nemeses |publisher=This American Life |date=December 16, 2011 |accessdate=February 12, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113002059/http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/453/nemeses |archivedate=January 13, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Previously, Gethard served as an editorial assistant for the popular ''[[Weird NJ]]'' and ''[[Weird US]]'' publications.
===Interactions with fans=== Gethard hitchhiked from Los Angeles to [[Bonnaroo]] (Tennessee) relying only on the good will of others to help him. He has a series of YouTube videos that document his trip. The videos include trips in vans and driving a firetruck.
''The Chris Gethard Show'' is well known for its audience interaction. One show featured a woman calling in to inquire about the purpose of the show. Gethard invited her to join them and she became a regular for four months.<ref name=ny_mag /> After this the notion of random, unknown fans becoming regular cast members became popular. The show continued this trend through its public access run, having a new "random" as a cast member for 15 episodes.
==Personal life== Gethard married Hallie Bulleit, band leader for ''The Chris Gethard Show'',<ref>{{cite web|last1=Fox|first1=Jesse David|title=Conversations About Death and Comedy With Chris Gethard|url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/01/conversations-about-death-comedy-with-gethard.html|website=Vulture|language=en|date=May 5, 2017}}</ref> on August 30, 2014 in Brooklyn, New York.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chris Gethard Ended Dating Affair And Married The Love Of His Life; Maintaining A Healthy Relationship With Wife And Career?|url=http://liverampup.com/entertainment/chris-gethard-ended-dating-affair-married-love-life-maintaining-healthy-relationship-wife-career.html|website=LIVERAMPUP}}</ref> The service was performed by fellow ''Chris Gethard Show'' cast member, Murf Meyer.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gordon|first1=Arielle|title=BV interview w/ Chris Gethard: "In the end I always ask myself — what would Jeff Rosenstock do?"|url=http://www.brooklynvegan.com/bv-interview-chris-gethard-talks-going-live-keeping-things-weird-on-new-season-of-tcgs/|website=BrooklynVegan|accessdate=August 23, 2017|date=August 1, 2017|quote=The people involved in the show are my family. In one case literally, as I married Hallie [Bulleit], the leader of our house band. Murf was our reverend. I was the reverend at his wedding, after he got engaged live on the show.}}</ref>
He is an avid fan of [[The Smiths]] and has two tattoos related to the band—[[Morrissey]]'s signature on his right shoulder (based on an actual signature he got in marker on his arm), and "It takes strength to be gentle and kind," a lyric from "[[I Know It's Over]]," on his right [[biceps]].<ref name="Smiths tattoos">{{cite news|last=Gethard|first=Chris|title=This Charming Band|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/books/2012/11/smiths_and_morrissey_biography_tony_fletcher_s_a_light_that_never_goes_out.html|newspaper=[[Slate (website)|Slate]]|date=November 30, 2012|accessdate=December 2, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121202041219/http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/books/2012/11/smiths_and_morrissey_biography_tony_fletcher_s_a_light_that_never_goes_out.html|archivedate=December 2, 2012|df=}}</ref>

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> |name = Dewey Balfa |image = Dewey_Balfa_Bordeaux_1977.jpg |caption = Dewey Balfa performing in 1977. |background = solo_singer |birth_date = {{birth date|1927|03|20}} |birth_place = Grand Louis, [[Louisiana]], U.S. |death_date = {{death date and age|1992|06|17|1927|03|20}} |death_place = Eunice, Louisiana, U.S. |instrument = [[Fiddle]] |genre = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[Cajun music|Cajun]] |occupation = Musician |years_active = 1948–1992 |associated_acts= [[The Balfa Brothers]] }} '''Dewey Balfa''' (March 20, 1927 – June 17, 1992) was an [[Americans|American]] [[Cajun]] fiddler and singer who contributed significantly to the popularity of [[Cajun music]]. Balfa was born near [[Mamou, Louisiana]]. He is perhaps best known for his 1964 performance at the [[Newport Folk Festival]] with Gladius Thibodeaux and Vinus LeJeune, where the group received an enthusiastic response from over seventeen thousand audience members. He sang the song "Parlez Nous à Boire" in the 1981 cult film ''[[Southern Comfort (1981 film)|Southern Comfort]]'', in which he had a small role.
==Early life== Dewey Balfa was born in Grand Louis, Louisiana, a small community west of [[Mamou, Louisiana|Mamou]].<ref name="savoy84p236">[[#Savoy84|Savoy 1984]], p. 236.</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Dewey Balfa and the Balfa Brothers|url=http://www.balfatoujours.com/brothers.html|accessdate=2009-10-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221131105/http://balfatoujours.com/brothers.html|archivedate=2009-02-21|df=}}</ref> He was the son of Amay (née Ardoin) and Charles Balfa who were sharecroppers.<ref>[[#Savoy84|Savoy 1984]], p. 237.</ref> Dewey had learned most of his songs from his grandmother and father who was a fiddle player.<ref name="savoy84p236" />
==Musical career== During [[World War II]], Dewey worked in a shipyard in [[Orange, Texas]].<ref name="savoy84p239">[[#Savoy84|Savoy 1984]], p. 239.</ref> After returning in 1948, he and his brothers Will and Rodney formed the Musical Brothers.<ref name="savoy84p239" /> In 1965, he formed [[The Balfa Brothers]] after an enthusiastic response from a performance at the [[Newport Folk Festival]]. This led to their first LP, produced by Swallow Records.
==Family== Dewey Balfa married Hilda Frugé when he was 22 in 1949. They had five children together: Nelda, Roberta, Norma, Dewey Jr., and [[Christine Balfa|Christine]].<ref>[[#Savoy84|Savoy 1984]], p. 241.</ref> Many of whom became musicians. Christine founded the band [[Balfa Toujours]] to continue the family tradition.
==Popularization of Cajun music== Dewey Balfa appears in a documentary file entitled "Les Blues de Balfa" produced by Yasha Aginsky. In one scene, Balfa is shown with Nathan Abshire entertaining a group of school children. Balfa gives a short lecture concerning the origins of Cajun music:
"We are here to tell you a little bit about what a Cajun is. A Cajun is a person who his homeland was France. Went into Nova Scotia, at the time Acadia, and settled there and was there for about a hundred years, and afterwards the British took over the territory and then the French-speaking people, the French descendants, known as the Acadians, came down to the South-Western part of Louisiana, and that was back in 1755. So over all of these years, your language, and your music has been preserved from daddy to son or daddy to daughter or momma to daughter."
